These very promising eco-evolutionary studies, striving to include a variety of relevant biological mechanisms, commonly depict species interactions in a simplified manner. For example, Norberg et al.
7 , Lasky
13 , and Thompson and Fronhofer
6 take all of the aforementioned aspects into consideration, and their models are important stepping-stones along the way to map out the relevance of species interactions under dispersal, evolution, and climate change. However, they only consider competitive interactions, and even those under more
7 or less
6, 13 restrictive assumptions: Norberg et al.
7 , for instance, set all intra- and interspecific interaction strengths to be equal, and Lasky
13 uses diffuse competition, whereby species share one common intra- and another common interspecific competition coefficient.
